dt.t: Many critics have {phrase}looked askance{/phrase} at the proposal.
That experienced pilot of the Broads looked {wi}askance{/wi} at his watch, and drew Allan aside at the first opportunity.

et: probably a sense development (influenced by {it}asqwynt{/it} "obliquely, {et_link|askew|askew}," and phonetically similar words) of earlier and Middle English {it}askaunce, a-skans, a-skaunces{/it} "in such a way that, as if, as if to say, artificially, deceptively," from {it}as-{/it} {et_link|as:1|as:1} + Old French {it}quanses, canses{/it} "as if, appearing as though," from {it}quanse-, canse-{/it} (going back to Latin {it}quam sī{/it} "as if") + {it}-s,{/it} adverbial suffix

Evidence for {it}quanses/canses,{/it} etc., is lacking in Anglo-French, suggesting that Middle English {it}a-skaunces{/it} may not have been directly borrowed from French; rather, the model for the word may have been Middle Dutch {it}als quansis{/it} with the same sense, with {it}quansis{/it} perhaps borrowed from French dialects adjacent to Dutch (cf. {it}fé lès qwanses{/it} "to pretend," Walloon of Liège according to {it}Französisches etymologisches Wörterbuch,{/it} vol. 2, p. 1416).

dt.t: Most scientists {it}looked askance at{/it} the new discovery.
